prospects.name: Phil wins the Tour
prospects.description:
Join Phil Gaimon in his bid to “win the Tour” as he takes on France’s most iconic mountains—The Tourmalet, Mont Ventoux, Alpe d’Huez and Galibier. This session captures the feel of those legendary ascents with 4 x 10-minute descending threshold intervals. Each one starting above threshold before easing down, forcing you to pace smart, clear the burn, and stay locked in until the summit.

​

Between climbs, you’ll get some recovery—time to spin the legs and imagine soaking in the views (or raiding a French bakery, Phil-style).

​

Physiologically, you’ll build muscular endurance, improve your ability to process oxygen, and train your body to go deep without breaking. Mentally, you’ll sharpen pacing skills and resilience—the hallmarks of any great climber.

prospects.name: Standing Starts
prospects.description:
_Standing Starts_ closely simulates a lifting session on the bike because it requires the engagement of your core, upper body, and lower body. It trains your ability to generate force through the pedals by ensuring you recruit ALL of your muscles to get those cranks turning. No matter your preferred discipline, these efforts are key to teaching your body to recruit all of the muscle fibers in your legs.

​

All of the benefits in this session come from hitting these 20-second efforts as hard as you possibly can. To do that, you need full recovery between each sprint, and you need to respect that recovery. These efforts should see you start at super low RPMs with very high torque. As you start and increase the effort, your cadence will naturally increase. **Your goal is to get your cadence as high as possible by the end of each 20-second effort.** To maximize your muscle recruitment, you want to both push down and pull up on the pedals at the start. Proper core engagement is a must - your legs need a good strong backboard to push against.

​

We understand that not everyone's trainer has the necessary resistance or the required stability to perform this workout as described. If you can't safely stand up, then you can get much of the same benefit by doing these efforts seated. If your trainer can’t handle the rapid change in speed or does not have high enough resistance at a super low cadence, then you can start the efforts at a higher cadence and treat them as “normal” all-out sprints.
prospects.notes:
**Before Strength**
This is a session that can be done indoors or outdoors.
If done outdoors, come to a slow roll in your largest Chain Ring and your 3rd or 4th smallest cog on your rear cassette. 
Complete the same set of 4 x 20sec maximal start efforts, with 6-8 minutes of easy spinning between.

prospects.name: The Bat
prospects.description:
While you're certainly going to feel this workout in your legs, it's what happens in your head over these six intervals that matter most. A sort of 'Applied Mental Training Program' session is a unique addition to the SUF library.

​

Over the course of the workout, you'll be taken through six different mental toughness tasks drawn from the SYSTM Mental Training Program (available here in the app). We'll teach you how to focus, use positive self-talk, and see an image of Future You to help you push through the Suffering.

​

From a physical point of view, this is a series of five-minute intervals with very high Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP) efforts at both ends. They pack the same training punch as much longer Sub-Threshold efforts with the added bonus of stimulating your MAP and Anaerobic Capacity (AC) simultaneously.

​

**Physiologically**: The first 30-second effort digs you into an anaerobic hole. Even though it is a MAP-based target, your heart rate and breathing rates (and thus ability to deliver oxygen) are still low, so your body must produce much of this power anaerobically. By the time you settle into the 4-minutes at just below FTP, your body will have produced an excess of metabolites responsible for that burning in your legs. Only by riding below FTP will your body clear them out since FTP is the tipping point where your body produces metabolites at the same rate it is clearing them. By holding you at FTP, your body cannot clear out that excess, forcing you to deal with the associated discomfort for the next 4-minutes.

Capping the effort off with a final 30-second surge requires that you dig into what is left of your AC while your body pushes you close to your VO2 max, or the point at which your body is using as much oxygen as it possibly can. The net result is a session that is great for improving FTP, MAP, and AC, regardless of your strengths and weaknesses.

​

**Psychologically**: Each 4-minute segment at just below FTP will end up feeling harder than it should, given your body is forced to stew in whatever excess metabolites you produced in the first 30-seconds. While it will be unpleasant, you should find it never really gets MORE unpleasant. In addition to the benefits from the actual mental training exercises, this preps you to have confidence in your ability to hold longer sustained FTP efforts. The final surge then shows you that even when you feel uncomfortable for that long, your body still has something more to give. Going through the Mental Training techniques while you're pushing through the discomfort will only make you stronger out on the road.

​

In some cultures, the bat symbolizes the death of old ways and the rise of new ones. Time to burn those old, bad habits and build some new, positive ones.

prospects.name: Catalunya: Costa Brava Coastline
prospects.description:
Today we’re going to be riding one of the most incredible roads of Spain's Catalan region, going from St Feliu de Guíxols over to Tossa de Mar and hugging the Costa Brava coastline the whole way. Continually undulating we’ll hit each of the eight rolling climbs hard, working at low cadence with high intensity to build strength. Mike will keep you focused on good form, though, and make sure you keep the power down on all the way over each summit.

​

It wouldn't be an On Location ride, though, if we didn't have a look at the scenic attractions along the way, though, so get ready for craggy rocks, turquoise clear waters, and a few opportunities to delve into the Costa Brava’s finest as we find out more about the region along this 21km route.

​

[Route on Strava](https://www.strava.com/routes/2967787441439728434)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Recovery Spin
prospects.description:
Don’t be afraid of the Two Rs: rest and recovery. Believe it or not, you get faster when your body is taking it easy after all that suffering. A recovery spin is a very low intensity ride, so easy that you’d feel embarrassed to ride so slowly if you didn’t know you were helping your body get so much faster.

​

A good recovery spin is done at a cadence above 90 RPM. While keeping power below 50% of FTP, or an RPE less than 2.5, and keeping your heart rate in Zone 1 the entire time. Recovery spins can be done outdoors, but due to the low power demands, they are often easier done on the trainer. Resist the voice of your inner Sufferlandrian telling you to go faster.

​

**Main Set**

30 minute @ RPE 1.5 -- 45% of FTP-- HR <70%

prospects.name: De Stig
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2020): De Stig is a 90-minute documentary film about life, but especially rehabilitation, by professional cyclist Stig Broeckx, who crashed heavily during the 2016 Tour of Belgium.

​

He was involved in a crash with two race motorcycles and nearly lost his life. The then-26-year-old Belgian was taken to hospital with serious head injuries, including a fractured skull and bleeding on the brain, and was in a coma for months. At the time doctors feared he may never regain consciousness.

​

Stig's story is a universal story of the bad luck of one young man and his endless perseverance and positivity to overcome. It’s a story of unconditional love from his family and friends. It’s a story of hope and even though many of us won’t face something as severe as Stig, we all struggle with life sometimes. There is a lesson in Stig’s contagious smile for all of us.

​

🚴 Workout: While we are all about the High-Intensity Interval Training that most of our videos dish out, riding to this Inspiration film is a great way to watch an interesting film while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: To Get To The Other Side
prospects.description:
While you might think the only way to improve your FTP is to ride at, or above, your existing FTP, that isn't always the case. Your body can only handle so much time above FTP in any given week (or month, for that matter). But that doesn’t mean you should sit around doing nothing the rest of the time.

​

Your body is most efficient at clearing out lactate and other metabolic byproducts at 80-95% of FTP. This is one of the few sessions where you can consistently sit at that intensity and let your body churn away at this nice, efficient effort level. It's the ideal workout to end a hard, three-day block or add in during a rest week. It will give your body a little training stimulus while still allowing it to recover from whatever tortures you've recently put it through.

prospects.name: Fairless
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2015): This is the story of Australian cycling legend Steve Fairless who at only twenty-six years old rode for Australia in the 1988 Seoul Olympics before giving up his sport to raise a family. Now at fifty, Steve’s finally ready to make a comeback, proving it’s never too late to chase your dreams.

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Costa Blanca: Puerto de la Vall de Ebo (Recharger Ride)
prospects.description:
This is an active recovery ride built with purpose. Low-intensity endurance work is paired with brief high-cadence neuromuscular activations to keep the nervous system awake without creating new fatigue. You’ll stay well below threshold throughout, allowing your body to absorb previous hard sessions and prepare for what’s ahead.

​

Set on the peaceful roads leading to the summit of Port de la Vall d’Ebo, this ride promotes circulation, technique, and mental reset. It’s ideal after race days or big training blocks — a smart session that helps you recover better, so you can train harder tomorrow. No ego, no watts chasing — just intentional recovery done right.

​

[**Wahoo Route**](https://www.strava.com/activities/13996505846)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Made This
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2024): In professional bike racing, we don't often see the whole picture. We only see the starts and the finishes, the breakaways and crashes, the near misses and podiums. Made This presented by Wahoo + MAAP is a series of behind-the-scenes, unfiltered front-row access with women's pro cycling team Lifeplus - Wahoo:

1. **Sisterhood: **Dedication, challenges, commitment, belief, family and sisterhood are all components of what it takes to be a professional racing team. In the first of a series of behind-the-scenes, unfiltered front-row access with team Lifeplus-Wahoo, MADE THIS is a collection of short films from MAAP Pro Team Racing that reveals what it takes to make a champion a champion.
2. **Prepared for anything: **The excitement of Holy Week at the Tour de Flanders is upon us, and Team Lifeplus-Wahoo is gearing up for a challenging ride. With 163km to conquer, featuring 12 climbs and seven cobbled stretches, not to mention seven slippery flat stone sections—all under a deluge of rain—anything could happen.
3. **Passion on the cobbles: **Join us as we dive deep into the chaotic and exhilarating world of the Paris-Roubaix, one of cycling's most grueling races. Amidst the cobblestones and mud, Team Lifeplus-Wahoo faces the ultimate test of endurance and skill. With a new lineup and high stakes, the team navigates the unpredictable nature of this legendary race, where luck can play a huge role and every second counts.
4. **Home sweet home: **After a fallow year for the tour, the team are eager to push for results in front of an expectant crowd. But instead of the warm welcome on familiar roads, disaster strikes the first morning of the race. As national news of the unfortunate event breaks, the team are left wondering if they'll be able to compete or if this becomes a home visit to forget. What follows is a true act of human kindness and a gesture that symbolises the unifying bond of the women's pro peloton.

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film is a recovery session. It's a very low-intensity ride, with your power remaining at or below 50% of FTP (an RPE less than 2.5 on a scale from 1 to 10) and your heart rate in Zone 1. The intensity and cadence targets will vary throughout this session to keep it interesting, but not so much that it distracts you from the story.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Open: 60
prospects.description: Sometimes you just need a steady endurance ride to clear the legs and head to make room for more serious sessions. This workout is set for a steady 65% FTP, but you can adjust the intensity whenever you like to match your workout goals. The video for this session is from the 2018 Tour de Suisse.

prospects.name: Tempo High Cadence: 4 x 3
prospects.description:
The training benefit of this session comes down to the uncomfortably high cadence you need to hold during each effort. Even though these efforts are under FTP, the high leg speed required will leave your system working harder than usual for the required power output.

By maintaining the highest cadence possible (without bouncing in the saddle) you end up pushing your neuromuscular coordination near its limits in a similar way to Cadence Builds.

​

With an emphasis on low torque (high RPM) efforts this session is polar opposite to sessions like GOAT and Power Station. Even though these efforts are short and below FTP the high cadence places more of a load on your cardiovascular system, so expect your heart rate and breathing to be higher than normal for the power.

​

Since muscles can only contract (pull) any given muscle will primarily move a joint in a single direction. When it comes to pedaling a bike, your quads and glutes can push the pedals down, while your hamstrings and hip flexors pull the pedals back up (with the help of your glutes and quads on the other leg). If you were to pedal with one leg (as you do in Cadence Drills) and your hamstrings and glutes were unable to contract, once you get to the bottom of the pedal stroke your leg would be stuck down there. No matter how hard you might try, your glutes and quads will do nothing to help you get that pedal all the way around. Suppose you do have both feet clipped in, and you are letting your opposite leg push down to bring your leg back up to 12 o'clock. If your quads and glutes are still contracting (pushing the pedal down) while the glutes and quads of your other leg are starting to push their pedal down, you will end up with one leg working against the other. You must relax the glutes and quads of one leg to get all of the power out of the glutes and quads of your other leg.

This is where neuromuscular coordination comes into play. During each pedal revolution, your legs have to “switch on” and “switch off” almost all of the muscles in your legs. By maintaining your highest cadence without bouncing, you are pushing all of the muscles in each leg to contract and relax (switch on and off) as quickly as possible.

While we give specific cadence targets in this session, everyone has a different limit to what cadence they can maintain before bouncing in the saddle. To get the intended benefit of this session you need to maintain the power targets at the highest cadence that YOU can maintain. For some that might be 105RPM, for others, it might be 150RPM. What matters is that you push YOUR neuromuscular system to its limits.

​

**Warm Up**

15 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of sets: 3

Rest between sets: 7 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

Interval repeats per: NA

**Interval**

3 minutes @ RPE 5 -- 80% of FTP -- 100+ RPM -- HR <95%

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Cadence Builds
prospects.description:
One of the best sessions for neuromuscular training, this drill asks you to progressively build from a cadence of 90 RPM to your MAX over 30 seconds, recover, and repeat several times. Cadence builds improve how you recruit your leg, gluteal, and core muscles throughout your pedal stroke by progressing to your maximal cadence. By reaching your highest cadence possible, you are training the 'on/off' switch in each muscle group to not only work faster but to have less overlap with your other muscle groups. This session trains your hamstring muscles to 'turn off' when your quads 'turn on' and vice-versa, resulting in a more efficient pedal stroke at both high and low cadences.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to The Knowledge podcast, by Wahoo Sports Science - The Benefits of High Cadence Training: [https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence](https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence)

prospects.name: Phil wins the Tour
prospects.description:
Join Phil Gaimon in his bid to “win the Tour” as he takes on France’s most iconic mountains—The Tourmalet, Mont Ventoux, Alpe d’Huez and Galibier. This session captures the feel of those legendary ascents with 4 x 10-minute descending threshold intervals. Each one starting above threshold before easing down, forcing you to pace smart, clear the burn, and stay locked in until the summit.

​

Between climbs, you’ll get some recovery—time to spin the legs and imagine soaking in the views (or raiding a French bakery, Phil-style).

​

Physiologically, you’ll build muscular endurance, improve your ability to process oxygen, and train your body to go deep without breaking. Mentally, you’ll sharpen pacing skills and resilience—the hallmarks of any great climber.

prospects.name: The Holy Week
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2018): The Holy Week tells the story from the eve of the Tour of Flanders right through until the tense finale on the Roubaix velodrome. Through the eyes of the riders, team staff, and devoted roadside fans, we go behind the scenes to capture the essence of the cobbled classics, and the emotions of one of the most compelling campaigns of recent years.

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film varies from endurance to tempo to sub-threshold. The higher intensity efforts are low enough that they won't distract you from the story while being just hard enough to help improve your FTP, oxygen utilization efficiency, and the ability to recover quickly between hard efforts.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Bavaria: Burgberg
prospects.description:
This may be a short workout, but it packs a serious punch—so lace up those gloves and get ready for 22 powerful 10-second seated sprints!

After a gentle warm-up leaving the picturesque village of Sulzberg, we’ll dive straight into our first block: 8 x 10-second high-cadence seated sprints with 50 seconds of recovery.

As the road naturally levels out, we’ll catch our breath before hitting the core of the workout—9 x 10-second low-cadence seated sprints with the same 50-second recovery, focusing on maintaining rock-solid form.

To close things out, we’ll return to the high-cadence style for a final round of 5 x 10-second sprints. This session is designed to sharpen muscle activation and improve recovery after intense efforts.

Finish strong, and I’ll see you in Burgberg!

​

With short near-maximal sprint efforts like these, you’ll recruit all of the muscle fibers in your legs. While cadence builds force your muscles to contract and relax as quickly as possible, this session forces your muscles to contract with maximal power. Just like cadence builds, this session becomes one of the best ways to train your neuromuscular system.

Even if your target event does not require you to complete maximal sprints, there is a substantial trickle-down efficiency effect to the longer-duration power efforts when you train your neuromuscular system.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/9866624296)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: The Model
prospects.description:
They say that beauty is in the eye of the beholder. And through the bleeding eyes of Sufferlandrians, what could possibly be more beautiful than the sharp, saw-tooth profile of the workout you see before you? Full of gorgeous, shapely, shimmering blocks of yellow Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP) efforts interspersed with mercifully brief and slightly inadequate recoveries, it's a real stunner.

​

But you know what's even better looking than this alluring workout? You (after you've completed the workout, that is). Originally designed by our Head of Sports Science, Neal Henderson, for his professional athletes, The Model is a beautiful portrait of MAP brutality. It's one of those sessions that you think you can't finish, but always somehow do. It will leave you breathless, feeling all tingly, a bit confused and lying in a blubbering heap. It's a look. It will also deliver a nice boost to your fitness that always looks and feels good.

​

A true love letter to the beauty of professional cycling, The Model features a banging soundtrack and thrilling footage from both the men's and women's pelotons. With its eclectic design, effects, and graphics, you'll find yourself unable to tear your eyes away from the action on screen (assuming you can lift them from your stem).

prospects.name: Open: 120
prospects.description: Sometimes you just need a steady endurance ride to clear the legs and head out to make room for a more serious session. This workout is set for a steady 65% FTP, but you can adjust the intensity whenever you like to match your workout goals. The video for this session is from the Road Race of The Hammer Series.

prospects.name: Costa Blanca: Puerto de la Vall de Ebo (Recharger Ride)
prospects.description:
This is an active recovery ride built with purpose. Low-intensity endurance work is paired with brief high-cadence neuromuscular activations to keep the nervous system awake without creating new fatigue. You’ll stay well below threshold throughout, allowing your body to absorb previous hard sessions and prepare for what’s ahead.

​

Set on the peaceful roads leading to the summit of Port de la Vall d’Ebo, this ride promotes circulation, technique, and mental reset. It’s ideal after race days or big training blocks — a smart session that helps you recover better, so you can train harder tomorrow. No ego, no watts chasing — just intentional recovery done right.

​

[**Wahoo Route**](https://www.strava.com/activities/13996505846)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: The Cure
prospects.description:
Do you have Couchlandrian Tendencies? This short but powerful workout will cure you of that affliction and reassert your inner Sufferlandrian. The session is based on a combination of specific micro-intervals (made famous by Japanese coach and physiologist Izumi Tabata) that we combined with classic tempo efforts. This gives you a superb mix of Anaerobic Capacity (AC), Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP), and FTP training stresses in one short workout to help you go faster and stay stronger for longer.

​

Now, for the sports science purists among you, the 'Tabata' intervals should actually be named 'Koichi' intervals, since it was Japanese speedskating coach Irisawa Koichi who first employed the use of the 20-seconds on / 10-seconds off intervals that Dr. Izumi then confirmed via physiology lab studies to yield the best mix of maximal aerobic and anaerobic stress among the different on/off protocols that he tested.

​

For this workout, we have toned down the original intensity of the Tabata intervals to target MAP rather than Anaerobic Capacity in order to be able to complete the 20/10 micro-intervals and then follow the short efforts immediately with sustained 80-100% of FTP intervals to replicate the kind of attack and then settle efforts that are common in cycling races.

​

From a physiological perspective, you’ll produce lots of lactate during the micro-intervals. Then the goal of the tempo and FTP efforts is to stress your body’s capacity to clear that lactate as quickly as possible. Effectively, we’re trying to maximize lactate 'flux.' For each successive round of the efforts, you’ll do one less micro-interval, and the tempo efforts will get shorter. But because you’re a Sufferlandrian, they won’t get easier, and the rest between sets will get shorter. The intensity for the tempo efforts will ramp up with each repetition. Fortunately for you, there are only 3 sets of efforts and you’ll be done in just 30 minutes. If you’ve set aside an hour for this workout, you’ll be happy to have those additional 30 minutes for recovery after this session.

prospects.name: Provence: Gorges de la Nesque
prospects.description:
We're in Provence, France for a stunning 24k ride - and workout - along the Gorges de la Nesque. As you learn all about the local lavender, craft beer, how to make nougat, and why there are all those holes in the ground, Mike will take you through a series of sub-threshold cadence changes and big sprints before cooling down on the run-in to Monieux.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/3930255146)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Wahoo Frontiers 2020
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2020): 2020 was one heck of a year. We released several episodes about Wahoo athletes pushing themselves and those around them into new frontiers. Here, we compile those videos for your viewing pleasure -- from the transformation and triumph of Ian Boswell to the downhill determination of Tahnée Seagrave and several stories in-between, there's something here to inspire everyone.

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: 14 Vise Grips
prospects.description:
You can never have too many tools in the shed. After years of lobbying, we finally convinced Grunter von Agony to share his favorite set of implements with us: the fabled _14 Vise Grips_. Taken individually, each of the 14 intervals might appear tame, incapable of inflicting a significant squeeze. But when expertly applied in the correct order, they apply just the right kind of pressure to turn a Couchlandrian into a Sufferlandrian, just like turning coal into diamonds.

​

While the duration of each Vise Grip varies (from 30 seconds to 2 minutes), the power targets and recovery durations between them remain constant. The first 30-second interval should feel like a Sunday stroll in the park, but by the end of the first 2-minute Vise Grip, you'll be cursing Grunter's name. As the intervals get shorter, time will appear to stretch. That final 30-second effort will feel like an eternity. When you roll up to the second set, you'll know what you're in for, so just put your head down and prepare yourself to crush or be crushed.

​

Once you make it through all 14 Vise Grips, you will have been north of your Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP) for a total of 16 minutes. Changing the duration of the efforts (while keeping the same recovery) stresses your Anaerobic Capacity (AC) in a more dynamic way than, say, a more straightforward on/off session like _Half is Easy_. Since the longer efforts have the same recovery duration as the shorter ones, you will eventually deplete your AC, forcing your body to rely on your MAP to hit the required power targets. As the intervals get shorter in the second half of each set, you'll find that you have just enough left in the tank to complete the next effort.

​

Ultimately this workout combines the advantages of shorter, higher-power intervals with longer recovery (great for building muscular strength) with the advantages of longer, higher-power intervals with inadequate recovery (great for driving up your MAP and improving your AC).

prospects.name: From the Ground Up - Season 3 Pt 4
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2023):

**Episode 6: Hours : Minutes : Seconds**

The final episode of Season 3, five separate stories that you have watched grow over the last 5 months, culminating in Leadville for the race. What is often missed in this project is that we truly believe in building a team, a family and more, that it would be even tougher to do alone. Sit down on your couch with some popcorn and a blanket, but don't forget to bring your friends - this one is full of moments that will make you want to get off the couch!

​

🚴 Workout: the workout accompanying this film varies from endurance to tempo to sub-threshold. The higher intensity efforts aren't the hardest you'll experience so that you can keep your attention on the film, however, they are just hard enough to help improve your FTP, oxygen utilization efficiency, and the ability to recover quickly between hard efforts. The workout intensity reflects the intensity of the riders in many places, so you may feel as if you're climbing Mont Ventoux or that you're a part of a sprint lead-out train on the run into the finish line.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Cadence Builds
prospects.description:
One of the best sessions for neuromuscular training, this drill asks you to progressively build from a cadence of 90 RPM to your MAX over 30 seconds, recover, and repeat several times. Cadence builds improve how you recruit your leg, gluteal, and core muscles throughout your pedal stroke by progressing to your maximal cadence. By reaching your highest cadence possible, you are training the 'on/off' switch in each muscle group to not only work faster but to have less overlap with your other muscle groups. This session trains your hamstring muscles to 'turn off' when your quads 'turn on' and vice-versa, resulting in a more efficient pedal stroke at both high and low cadences.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to The Knowledge podcast, by Wahoo Sports Science - The Benefits of High Cadence Training: [https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence](https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence)

prospects.name: Tapers
prospects.description:
When it comes to "peaking", or performing at your absolute best on a given day, the key is nailing your Taper. The term "Taper" refers to how you train in the week or so before your target event to ensure you deliver your best performance. Generally, tapering means reducing your total training volume but continuing to hit some high-intensity efforts. While there are individual variations in the best way to taper, this session has been used by countless professionals leading into the biggest races of their lives -- athletes like World Champions Rohan Dennis and Flora Duffy.

​

With 3 sets of micro-intervals (40/20s, 30/30s, and 20/40s) you will hit your system with just enough intensity to keep your legs sharp and responsive, without adding any real fatigue. Outside of those 3 sets of micro-intervals, this session is purposefully short and easy. This is a preparation session, not a training session! After all, your event is just around the corner and all of the important training is behind you. Riding harder or longer today will do absolutely nothing to increase your fitness by event day; in fact, all that would do is increase your fatigue, which will only hurt your performance. Rather, this session makes sure your body is humming along and ready to perform on the big day.

prospects.name: Fursa
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2021): Fursa is the Swahili word for opportunity. Together with Amani Racing, we are supporting athletes from East Africa with the opportunity to race against the top gravel riders in the World. Four elite cyclists have been chosen to come to the US and race SBT GRVL, BWR Asheville & Vermont Overland developing new pathways for athletes from East Africa to show their full potential.

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film is a recovery session. Intensity is low, with power remaining at or below 50% of FTP (2.5 on a scale from 1 to 10) with heart rate targets entirely in Zone 1. The intensity and cadence targets will vary throughout this session to keep it interesting, but not so much that it distracts you from the story.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Primers
prospects.description: Whether you have a 4DP® fitness test coming up, a group ride you want to smash, that event you have been training all winter for, or even just a fun route you want to have a great ride on, this is the perfect session to do the day before. Unlike other SYSTM sessions, this one should not be viewed as a stand-alone “training” session, but rather, the ace up your sleeve you pull out when that big ride comes around. The key to this session is having you spend just enough time right around threshold, with sufficient recovery between efforts and a handful of sprints to prime all of your systems for tomorrow's event.

prospects.name: Full Frontal (4DP Assessment)
prospects.description:
Full Frontal: The Complete One.

We recommend the Full Frontal 4DP fitness assessment for:

- Experienced riders.
- Athletes with experience pacing maximal efforts / fitness testing.
- Those about to start—or who have just finished—a training plan.

This is our full 4DP fitness test and is the only test that exposes every aspect of your unique physiology in a single hour. Developed by Head of Wahoo Sports Science Coach Neal Henderson, Full Frontal uses the same lab-verified testing protocol that Coach Neal has used at the highest level for over a decade with professional and amateur athletes.

​

This test will provide you with a complete Four-Dimensional Power profile, identify your Rider Type, and tell you exactly what aspects of your fitness you need to focus on to become a more complete cyclist. More importantly, SYSTM will then use your results to set personalized power targets for all of your workouts based on your unique profile, resulting in the most precise, effective workouts available. Your results will also be used to tailor all of your training plans.

​

We recommend re-testing with Full Frontal every 8-12 weeks or as prescribed by your training plan.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to '[Why Fitness Testing Matters](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/testing-testing-1-2-3-why-fitness-testing-matters)' on The Knowledge Podcast by Wahoo Sports Science

​

[Here's some more information on how to get the most from your fitness test.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterFitnessAssessment)

prospects.name: 03. Establishing the Goal Setting Habit
prospects.description:
**GOAL SETTING**

A clear plan of action is essential to any undertaking. Setting concrete, actionable goals will keep you motivated and on track; whether you’re eyeing the top podium step or the summit of the local climb. We will help assess where you are today, where you want to go, and identify the steps needed to get there.

​

In this module, you will enable consistent progress by creating a habit of identifying monthly and weekly goals, with weekly rewards for achieving those goals.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

​

​

​

​

​

​

prospects.name: 04. Getting Positive
prospects.description:
Thoughts matter. To accomplish big goals you need the ability to maintain a positive mindset, regardless of what life gives you. Here's an overview of the power of maintaining a positive mindset. We’ll introduce specific techniques that will help you identify negative thoughts, see obstacles as opportunities, and take a more positive path forward.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 05. Remembering Why
prospects.description:
Focus is essential to high performance. Without it, you can become distracted, give in to self-doubt, and struggle to motivate yourself. Strengthen your willpower through a deep understanding of your key motivators and then develop a system to remind you of them on a daily basis.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 06. Relaxing to Recover
prospects.description:
Here you will complete a full Progressive Muscle Relaxation session. It’s part guided meditation and part focus exercise. You should listen to this module at least once per week to get in tune with your body, release tension, and maximize recovery.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 07. Positive Self-Talk
prospects.description:
Improve your confidence and performance through three types of positive self-talk: Motivational, Instructional, and Reward. Here, we’ll look at the subtle and not-so-subtle effects that words have on our attitude and performance. You’ll listen more closely to the way you talk to yourself so you can improve that internal dialogue and become your own biggest fan.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to '[The Power of Positive Mental Strategies](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/episode-29-how-to-use-positive-self-talk-to-get-through-tough-moments-on-a-ride-mental-strategies)' on The Knowledge Podcast by Wahoo Fitness.

prospects.name: 08. Improving Focus
prospects.description:
Develop an understanding of why focused concentration is so important to your performance. We will delve into what it means to be in “The Zone," look at the psychology and the physiology of peak performance, and what it takes to get there.

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 10. First Month Review & Improve
prospects.description:
You’ll look back at each of your weekly goals, as well as your overall goal for the month, to see how you did. This is your chance to give yourself a pat on the back, celebrate your successes, and identify how you’re going to do even better.

​

After looking to see what the past month can teach you, you’re going to turn your attention towards what lies ahead, setting new monthly and weekly goals.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 11. The Successful Training Habit
prospects.description:
Let's zoom in on how you actually train, day in and day out. Great training sessions don’t just happen. You have to make a conscious effort, get everything together, then actually do the work. Successful athletes don’t leave their training to chance—they have a specific routine they go through **EVERY. SINGLE. TIME.** The more deliberate you are with your thoughts and actions before, during, and after your workouts, the better your training habit becomes and the greater your progress.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 12. Workout Review
prospects.description:
We’re going to take the techniques you've learned during the “Monthly Review and Improve“ module, and apply them to your training sessions. This module should be completed immediately after finishing a workout. Have your workbook with you so after the cool-down you can start the workout review exercise immediately.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

prospects.name: 17. Overcoming Obstacles
prospects.description:

As a visualization exercise, this module is meant to be listened to whenever you feel stuck—whether that’s due to an obstacle you can’t see a way around, an injury, a loss of motivation, or any other reason which makes you doubt yourself. Even if you don’t have an obstacle right now, it’s a good idea to go through the module so you know what it’s about and when to use it. prospects.name: Total Newbie Yoga
prospects.description: Yoga-curious but don't know where to start? This session is a great place to dip your toes in. This easy, basic routine will introduce you to some simple foundational moves while giving you a little stretch and some light strength work at the same time. Think of it as the gateway drug to bringing yoga into your life.

prospects.name: Basic Yoga Poses
prospects.description: Throughout the SYSTM yoga program there are several basic, foundational moves that form the core of the routines. This session takes you through those moves in detail so you can master them and their more difficult variations.

prospects.name: Super Easy Stretch Routine I
prospects.description: Are you looking for a simple stretching routine you can do on a regular basis? New to yoga? Designed for yoga beginners, this gentle yoga session will get you on the road to a more flexible you. You've said for years you'd start stretching. Now's your chance.

prospects.name: Loosen Neck and Shoulders
prospects.description: Cycling can put a lot of strain on your neck and shoulders, especially if you spend a lot of time down in the drops or in an aero position. This session will help loosen your neck and shoulders with a series of exercises that will release tension and have you feeling relaxed and ready to hit it again.

prospects.name: Morning Yoga Routine
prospects.description: In this sequence, we start with a short breathing exercise to relax the body and calm the mind, then mobilize joints throughout the body. From there we move into deeper stretches for the hips and hamstrings and finish with a short meditation.

prospects.name: Basic Yoga Poses
prospects.description: Throughout the SYSTM yoga program there are several basic, foundational moves that form the core of the routines. This session takes you through those moves in detail so you can master them and their more difficult variations.

prospects.name: Chest & Shoulder Strength
prospects.description:
This yoga sequence is designed to strengthen the upper body, targeting the shoulders, chest, triceps, and core. It's an ideal routine to practice in the morning or before a workout to activate muscles throughout the body. The intensity can be increased by lifting the knees during push-ups, providing a challenge to work towards.

​

The objectives are to strengthen the shoulders, chest, triceps, and core, practice synchronizing breath and movement, and potentially alleviate lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Half Sun Salutations
- Triceps Push-Ups
- Plank
- Child
- Downward Dog
- Puppy
- Chest Stretch
- Triceps Stretch
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: End Of Day Stretch
prospects.description:
This slow and stretchy sequence is ideal for practicing at the end of a long day at work or after travel. It focuses on opening up the chest and shoulders, stretching the neck and forearms, and releasing tension in the calves, hamstrings, hips, and lower back. These poses can also be used after a workout for a comprehensive full-body stretch.

​

The objectives are to stretch the neck, shoulders, triceps, chest, and forearms; release tension in the lower back, hips, hamstrings, calves, ankles, and feet; transition the body into parasympathetic "rest or digest" mode after exercise; and help alleviate lower and mid back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Puppy
- Screaming Toe
- Neck Stretch
- Ankle Stretch
- Chest Stretch
- Forearm Stretch
- Downward Dog
- Revolved Standing Forward Bend
- Low Lunge Chest Opener
- Dead Pigeon
- Reclining Spinal Twist

prospects.name: Neck and Upper Back Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we improve mobility in the neck, shoulders, upper and mid-back, open up the chest and shoulders and relieve tension at the lower back to help alleviate neck, shoulder, and interscapular pain. You can practice it in the morning or the evening.

prospects.name: Recovery Booster
prospects.description: It may seem counterintuitive, but it's during recovery when you actually get stronger and consolidate the gains you've made while training. Without proper recovery, you won't improve. This session helps boost your recovery time, relaxing you and ensuring you give your body the chance to grow stronger.

prospects.name: Hip Flexor and Groin Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we release the hip flexors and groin and stretch the hamstrings and calves. It's a great session to do after a workout or in the evening to prevent and alleviate lower back pain.

prospects.name: Super Easy Stretch Routine I
prospects.description: Are you looking for a simple stretching routine you can do on a regular basis? New to yoga? Designed for yoga beginners, this gentle yoga session will get you on the road to a more flexible you. You've said for years you'd start stretching. Now's your chance.

prospects.name: Lower Back Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we release tension in the hips—the groin, glutes, piriformis, TFL, and external hip rotators, stretch the calves and hamstrings and re-align the pelvis. It's a great session to practice in the morning or the evening to prevent and alleviate lower back pain.

prospects.name: Thoracic Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we improve thoracic and shoulder mobility, open up the chest and stretch the lats, shoulders, triceps, calves, and hamstrings to improve posture, facilitate better breathing and help to alleviate upper back, interscapular, and neck pain. You can practice it in the morning or the evening.

prospects.name: Foot & Ankle Recovery
prospects.description:
In this restorative sequence, the focus is on mobilizing the toes, feet, and ankles, stretching the calves and hamstrings, and opening up the hips. The session begins with a calming breathing technique, followed by a simple foot massage to introduce movement from the toes up to the heel. With increased range of motion, the routine progresses to gentle, dynamic stretches for the calves, hamstrings, and hips. Since feet are often neglected and subjected to high demands from activities like running or cycling, practicing this sequence at least once a week helps to rebalance and address this issue.

​

The objectives are to improve mobility in the feet and ankles, stretch the calves and hamstrings, and open up the hips.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Easy Seat
- Box Breathing
- Foot Massage
- Downward Dog
- Screaming Toe
- Yoga Squat
- Ankle Stretch
- Ankle Mobilisations
- Windscreen Wipers

prospects.name: Post-Workout Cool-Down
prospects.description: This gentle cool-down is designed to completely unwind you after your ride…and potentially send you to sleep. We move systematically through the body, loosening up and stretching out tight muscles. Try to stay relaxed throughout while breathing in and out through your nose.

prospects.name: Morning Yoga Routine
prospects.description: In this sequence, we start with a short breathing exercise to relax the body and calm the mind, then mobilize joints throughout the body. From there we move into deeper stretches for the hips and hamstrings and finish with a short meditation.

prospects.name: Supple Spine & Hips
prospects.description:
This classic yoga sequence enhances mobility in the spine and hips while stretching the calves, hamstrings, hip flexors, and lower back. As you become familiar with the routine, you can begin to focus on synchronizing your breath with your movements, aiming to use nasal breathing as much as possible. It is an excellent practice for the morning to warm up and improve focus, or it can be done directly after a workout to help prevent extreme muscle stiffness.

​

The objectives are to improve mobility in the spine and hips, stretch the calves, hamstrings, hip flexors, and lower back, practice synchronizing breath and movement, and potentially alleviate lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Half Sun Salutations
- Downward Dog
- Crescent Lunge
- Bridge
- Reclining Spinal Twist
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Post-Workout Cool-Down
prospects.description: This gentle cool-down is designed to completely unwind you after your ride…and potentially send you to sleep. We move systematically through the body, loosening up and stretching out tight muscles. Try to stay relaxed throughout while breathing in and out through your nose.

prospects.name: Mobilize Your Body
prospects.description:
In this video, we focus on mobilizing the wrists, elbows, shoulders, neck, spine, hips, ankles, and toes to enhance overall mobility throughout the body. It is an excellent routine to practice in the morning or evening to alleviate stiffness.

​

The objectives are to increase mobility in the wrists, elbows, shoulders, neck, spine, hips, and ankles.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Screaming Toe
- Wrist Circles
- Elbow Circles
- Shoulder Circles
- Neck Circles
- Thunderbolt
- Kneeling Cat-Cow
- Thoracic Spine Circles
- Seated Twists
- Hip Circles
- Squat Twists
- Standing Forward Bends
- Reclining Hip Circles
- Windscreen Wipers
- Ankle Mobilisations
- Knees-To-Chest

prospects.name: Lower Back Release
prospects.description:
This video is designed to alleviate tightness in the lower back by releasing tension in the lower back, glutes, piriformis, groin, hamstrings, and calves through a series of reclining hip-opening poses combined with deep, diaphragmatic breathing.

​

The objectives are to stretch the lower back, glutes, piriformis, groin, hamstrings, and calves, improve mobility in the hips and spine, and help alleviate lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Wind-Relieving
- Reclining Spinal Twist
- Knees-To-Chest
- Reclining Hand-To-Big-Toe
- Dead Pigeon
- Happy Baby

prospects.name: Breathing to Crush Them
prospects.description: This is the breathing technique used by Navy Seals to help them focus and find calm before major operations. Learn and use this technique before heading into your own major events and races.

prospects.name: Improving Posture
prospects.description: Most cyclists suffer from rounded shoulders and a curved spine as a result of hours spent in the riding position. This series will release tension in your upper back and get you standing up straight and powerful again.

prospects.name: Basic Yoga Poses
prospects.description: Throughout the SYSTM yoga program there are several basic, foundational moves that form the core of the routines. This session takes you through those moves in detail so you can master them and their more difficult variations.

prospects.description: Get out of your habitual movement patterns and get ready to take on the day with this activation session. You'll flow through a series of standing yoga poses to simultaneously challenge your strength, flexibility, and range of motion, leaving you feeling energized.

prospects.name: Super Easy Stretch Routine I
prospects.description: Are you looking for a simple stretching routine you can do on a regular basis? New to yoga? Designed for yoga beginners, this gentle yoga session will get you on the road to a more flexible you. You've said for years you'd start stretching. Now's your chance.

prospects.name: Side Bends
prospects.description: If you're pushing yourself hard, it's likely you're getting stiff and sore all over. Side bends are one of my favorite ways to deal with general soreness. They're also perfect for cyclists who typically suffer from poor lateral flexibility.

prospects.name: Upper Body Strength
prospects.description: Those things you use to type and lift up your coffee cup? Yeah, those could be a bit stronger. So it's time to build strength in your upper body—in the hands, wrists, arms, shoulders, chest, and core. It is based around Sun Salutation, a yoga sequence that builds strength, increases power, and improves endurance.

prospects.name: The One For Your Hips
prospects.description:
This classic yoga sequence is designed to enhance hip mobility by stretching the hip flexors, glutes, groin, hamstrings, and calves through a series of static poses. The routine emphasizes releasing tension with each exhalation. It is particularly effective for alleviating lower back pain and improving hip range of motion. This sequence can be practiced at any time of day.

​

The objectives are to improve hip mobility, stretch the hip flexors, glutes, groin, hamstrings, and calves, practice nasal breathing with movement, and potentially alleviate lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Low Lunge
- Downward Dog Split
- Lizard
- Pigeon
- Happy Baby
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Core Strengtheners I
prospects.description: The power to to put watts to the pedals comes not just from your legs, but from your core. When your core is strong and stable, you can generate more power, more efficiently. You'll also suffer less back pain. With those goals in mind, this sequence strengthens the abs, obliques, and lower back.

prospects.name: Yoga for Travel
prospects.description: If you're traveling and will be off your bike for some time, you might feel that all is lost. But we've created a routine for travelers to keep you balanced, loose, and strong. Do this daily while on the road so you'll be in top condition when you can get back home.

prospects.name: Super Easy Stretch Routine II
prospects.description: You've just finished a difficult training session. You probably just want to curl up in a ball, but to make sure your body stays limber and flexible this sequence will stretch you out and open you up. You'll be ready to hit it again in no time.

prospects.name: Hamstring and Calf Flexibility
prospects.description: Cyclists are notorious for poor hamstring and calf flexibility. But these muscles can only be properly engaged when they're flexible. This series will increase your range of motion, boosting performance while helping you avoid injury.

prospects.name: Scapular Stability
prospects.description: In this Beginner / Intermediate sequence, we stabilize the muscles that support your shoulder blades, activate the posterior chain, strengthen the core and stretch the chest and fronts of the shoulders. This helps reduce your risk of neck and shoulder injury, alleviate neck and interscapular pain, and improve your posture. It's a great session to do in the morning or before a workout.

prospects.name: Core Stability

It's a great session to do in the morning or pre-workout.

prospects.name: Lower Back Recovery

It's a great session to practice in the morning or the evening to prevent and alleviate lower back pain.

prospects.name: Core Strengtheners II
prospects.description: Building on the gains you've achieved after doing the Core Strengtheners exercises several times, this session further strengthens the core.

You can practice it in the morning or the evening.

This session will help loosen your neck and shoulders with a series of exercises that will release tension and have you feeling relaxed and ready to hit it again.

prospects.description: This routine is designed to open up the hips—the hip flexors, rotators, and glutes—and stretch the hamstrings. The session guides you through a series of lunges and finishes with Lizard and Pigeon pose. You can practice it in the morning, before or after a ride. Experiment to see what works best for you.

prospects.name: Chest & Shoulder Strength
prospects.description:
This yoga sequence is designed to strengthen the upper body, targeting the shoulders, chest, triceps, and core. It's an ideal routine to practice in the morning or before a workout to activate muscles throughout the body. The intensity can be increased by lifting the knees during push-ups, providing a challenge to work towards.

​

The objectives are to strengthen the shoulders, chest, triceps, and core, practice synchronizing breath and movement, and potentially alleviate lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Half Sun Salutations
- Triceps Push-Ups
- Plank
- Child
- Downward Dog
- Puppy
- Chest Stretch
- Triceps Stretch
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Pre-Ride Warm-Up
prospects.description:
This sequence is designed to activate your posterior chain—the calves, hamstrings, glutes, lower, upper, and mid-back, as well as your core—the abs and obliques. It’s crucial that you engage these muscles before every ride to give you maximum power, speed, and endurance on the bike.

​

[https://wahoosystm.com/WarmingupTheEngine](https://wahoosystm.com/WarmingupTheEngine)

prospects.name: Post-Workout Cool-Down
prospects.description: This gentle cool-down is designed to completely unwind you after your ride…and potentially send you to sleep. We move systematically through the body, loosening up and stretching out tight muscles. Try to stay relaxed throughout while breathing in and out through your nose.

prospects.name: Morning Yoga Routine
prospects.description: In this sequence, we start with a short breathing exercise to relax the body and calm the mind, then mobilize joints throughout the body. From there we move into deeper stretches for the hips and hamstrings and finish with a short meditation.

prospects.name: Abs & Obliques
prospects.description:
This challenging core stability workout is designed to strengthen the abs, obliques, and lower back. It engages all three planes of motion—sagittal (planks), frontal (side planks), and transverse (poses with rotation)—to achieve maximum core strength and stability. It is an excellent routine to practice in the morning or as a standalone session.

​

The primary objective is to strengthen the core, including the abs, obliques, and lower back.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Plank
- Locust
- Spider Planks
- Child’s Pose
- Side Plank Variations
- Boat Variations
- Leg Raises
- Reclining Spinal Twist

prospects.name: Recovery Booster
prospects.description: It may seem counterintuitive, but it's during recovery when you actually get stronger and consolidate the gains you've made while training. Without proper recovery, you won't improve. This session helps boost your recovery time, relaxing you and ensuring you give your body the chance to grow stronger.

prospects.name: Lower Back Release
prospects.description:
This video is designed to alleviate tightness in the lower back by releasing tension in the lower back, glutes, piriformis, groin, hamstrings, and calves through a series of reclining hip-opening poses combined with deep, diaphragmatic breathing.

​

The objectives are to stretch the lower back, glutes, piriformis, groin, hamstrings, and calves, improve mobility in the hips and spine, and help alleviate lower back pain.

​

prospects.name: Spinal Flexibility
prospects.description:
This classic yoga sequence focuses on enhancing spinal flexibility by moving the spine through flexion, extension, rotation, and lateral flexion. It targets the shoulders, lats, obliques, lower back, quads, and glutes. This routine is excellent for increasing range of motion and reducing stiffness throughout the body. It can be practiced in the morning to help wake up or directly after a workout to prevent pain and stiffness.

​

The objectives are to increase spine and shoulder mobility, stretch the shoulders, lats, obliques, lower back, quads, and glutes, and reduce overall stiffness.

​

As you become familiar with the routine, you can work on synchronizing your breath with your movements, aiming to breathe in and out through your nose throughout. It is an excellent practice for the morning to sharpen your focus or directly after a workout to help prevent muscle stiffness.

The objectives are to improve mobility in the spine and hips, strengthen the hips and quads, stretch the calves, hamstrings, hip flexors, and groin, and practice synchronizing breath and movement.

prospects.name: Neck and Upper Back Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we improve mobility in the neck, shoulders, upper and mid-back, open up the chest and shoulders and relieve tension at the lower back to help alleviate neck, shoulder, and interscapular pain. You can practice it in the morning or the evening.

prospects.name: Breathing to Crush Them
prospects.description: This is the breathing technique used by Navy Seals to help them focus and find calm before major operations. Learn and use this technique before heading into your own major events and races.

prospects.name: Morning Yoga Routine
prospects.description: In this sequence, we start with a short breathing exercise to relax the body and calm the mind, then mobilize joints throughout the body. From there we move into deeper stretches for the hips and hamstrings and finish with a short meditation.

prospects.name: Improving Posture
prospects.description: Most cyclists suffer from rounded shoulders and a curved spine as a result of hours spent in the riding position. This series will release tension in your upper back and get you standing up straight and powerful again.

prospects.name: Balance and Agility
prospects.description: Maintaining effective cycling form when you're under pressure requires substantial balance, coordination, agility, and core strength. This series will develop those capabilities so you can put down the power when it really matters.

prospects.name: Super Easy Stretch Routine II
prospects.description: You've just finished a difficult training session. You probably just want to curl up in a ball, but to make sure your body stays limber and flexible this sequence will stretch you out and open you up. You'll be ready to hit it again in no time.

prospects.name: Full Body Mobility
prospects.description: This sequence is designed to improve the range of motion throughout the body, focusing on the spine, shoulders, and hips. It combines twists, side bends, and balance poses to enhance total body flexibility and agility.

prospects.name: End Of Day Stretch
prospects.description:
This slow and stretchy sequence is ideal for practicing at the end of a long day at work or after travel. It focuses on opening up the chest and shoulders, stretching the neck and forearms, and releasing tension in the calves, hamstrings, hips, and lower back. These poses can also be used after a workout for a comprehensive full-body stretch.

​

The objectives are to stretch the neck, shoulders, triceps, chest, and forearms; release tension in the lower back, hips, hamstrings, calves, ankles, and feet; transition the body into parasympathetic "rest or digest" mode after exercise; and help alleviate lower and mid back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Puppy
- Screaming Toe
- Neck Stretch
- Ankle Stretch
- Chest Stretch
- Forearm Stretch
- Downward Dog
- Revolved Standing Forward Bend
- Low Lunge Chest Opener
- Dead Pigeon
- Reclining Spinal Twist

prospects.name: Scapular Stability
prospects.description: In this Beginner / Intermediate sequence, we stabilize the muscles that support your shoulder blades, activate the posterior chain, strengthen the core and stretch the chest and fronts of the shoulders. This helps reduce your risk of neck and shoulder injury, alleviate neck and interscapular pain, and improve your posture. It's a great session to do in the morning or before a workout.

prospects.name: The One For Your Hips
prospects.description:
This classic yoga sequence is designed to enhance hip mobility by stretching the hip flexors, glutes, groin, hamstrings, and calves through a series of static poses. The routine emphasizes releasing tension with each exhalation. It is particularly effective for alleviating lower back pain and improving hip range of motion. This sequence can be practiced at any time of day.

​

The objectives are to improve hip mobility, stretch the hip flexors, glutes, groin, hamstrings, and calves, practice nasal breathing with movement, and potentially alleviate lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Low Lunge
- Downward Dog Split
- Lizard
- Pigeon
- Happy Baby
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Core Strengtheners I
prospects.description: The power to to put watts to the pedals comes not just from your legs, but from your core. When your core is strong and stable, you can generate more power, more efficiently. You'll also suffer less back pain. With those goals in mind, this sequence strengthens the abs, obliques, and lower back.

prospects.name: Hamstring and Calf Flexibility
prospects.description: Cyclists are notorious for poor hamstring and calf flexibility. But these muscles can only be properly engaged when they're flexible. This series will increase your range of motion, boosting performance while helping you avoid injury.

prospects.name: Peak Pose Wheel
prospects.description:
This sequence builds towards the advanced backbend, Wheel pose. To prepare for this pose, the routine focuses on mobilizing the spine and shoulders and opening up the fronts of the hips. It is best practiced when fully warmed up, with careful attention to the lower back and only moving within safe ranges of motion. For those who can practice Wheel safely, it serves as an excellent counterpose to common postures from cycling or sitting at a desk, potentially alleviating lower back, upper back, and shoulder pain. For those not yet ready for Wheel, the other poses in this sequence are also effective for addressing muscular imbalances.

​

The objectives are to increase spinal and shoulder mobility, stretch the abs, chest, and fronts of the shoulders, open up the hip flexors, activate the glutes, and help alleviate lower and upper back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Supported Bridge
- Thunderbolt—Shoulder Rolls
- Kneeling Cat-Cow
- Puppy
- Downward Facing Dog
- Cobra
- Low Lunge with Shoulder Opener
- Bridge
- Wheel
- Windscreen Wipers

prospects.description:
In this restorative sequence, the focus is on mobilizing the toes, feet, and ankles, stretching the calves and hamstrings, and opening up the hips. The session begins with a calming breathing technique, followed by a simple foot massage to introduce movement from the toes up to the heel. With increased range of motion, the routine progresses to gentle, dynamic stretches for the calves, hamstrings, and hips. Since feet are often neglected and subjected to high demands from activities like running or cycling, practicing this sequence at least once a week helps to rebalance and address this issue.

​

The objectives are to improve mobility in the feet and ankles, stretch the calves and hamstrings, and open up the hips.

The objectives include improving balance, proprioception, and body awareness; strengthening the knees, quads, and glutes; opening up the hips and chest; enhancing mobility in the spine; boosting focus and concentration; and practicing diaphragmatic, nasal breathing.

prospects.name: Recovery Booster
prospects.description: It may seem counterintuitive, but it's during recovery when you actually get stronger and consolidate the gains you've made while training. Without proper recovery, you won't improve. This session helps boost your recovery time, relaxing you and ensuring you give your body the chance to grow stronger.

prospects.name: Breathing to Crush Them
prospects.description: This is the breathing technique used by Navy Seals to help them focus and find calm before major operations. Learn and use this technique before heading into your own major events and races.

prospects.name: Full Body 01
prospects.description:
_Want a strength training routine that covers all the bases? Our Full Body Strength series is exactly what you’re after, offering a well-rounded series of exercises that covers the lower body, core, posterior chain, and upper body. With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time._

​

This is the first routine in the Full Body series. It introduces the most basic versions of moves that make up the majority of this program. Some of these moves may seem very basic but we encourage you to focus on perfect form and execution during these early levels so that when we turn up the heat you have things nailed. As you'll see, all the exercises at the lower levels will progress in a similar fashion going forward. We're building strength, but also fine-tuning your nervous system. As the program progresses you'll be asked to complete more difficult variations on each foundational move.

​

As with all the strength training routines, it helps if you’ve done a warm-up before getting started. That can be one of your favorite yoga routines, riding your bike on the trainer for 5-10 minutes, or doing a personal stretching routine.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you? [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Kneeling Hip Drive - Hands Over Head
- Kneeling Hip Drive - Hands Side to Side
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Bent Leg Tip at the Hip
- Goblet Squat
- Single-Leg Squat
- Backward Lunge
- Hip Hinge with Reach
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Push-Up on Knees
- Back Extension
- Quadruped with Leg Lifts
- Plank with Leg Lifts

prospects.name: Recovery Session A
prospects.description:
These recovery sessions are easy enough that you get the rest you need, but work you hard enough that your body continues to adapt to the new demands you place on it. You might see these sessions as too short and too easy to be beneficial, but just like a proper recovery spin, active recovery is infinitely better than doing nothing at all. Given how short this session is, we strongly recommend also doing a Yoga Session in the app first. Something like Mobilize and Activate, Balance and Agility, or Full Body Mobilization.

​

**Exercises Included**

- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hands Up
- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hands to Side
- High Plank
- Plank
- Hip Bridge
- Bent Leg Tip at the Hip
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands Up
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands to Side

prospects.name: Recovery Session B
prospects.description:
This session is designed to keep your body familiar with the basic movements of strength training without adding any extra fatigue to your system. This keeps your body adapted while allowing it to fully recover. To make the most out of your strength gains, you need to balance the hard work with adequate recovery. Given how short this session is, we strongly recommend completing a supplementary Yoga Session after this video. Something like Improving Posture, Shake Off the Day or Recovery Booster would be perfect.

​

**Exercises Included**

- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hands Over Head
- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hips Side to Side
- High Plank to Pigeon Pose
- Plank with Leg Lifts
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Fast Lateral Lunges with Knees Up
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands Up
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands Side to Side

prospects.name: Posterior Chain Focus 01
prospects.description:
_The primary objective of the Posterior Chain Series is to activate and strengthen the muscles on the back side of your body. This includes everything from your powerful glutes, hamstrings, and calves to the postural muscles of your upper back and neck._

​

Your posterior chain is responsible for back and hip extension as well as knee flexion. It is vital in maintaining optimal posture during cycling and running in addition to water position in swimming. In this first session, we introduce some basic movements that focus on the activation and stabilization of posterior chain muscles. These moves include a combination of eccentric (lengthening), concentric (shortening), and isometric (holding) contractions. They provide your body with the foundation for more demanding moves to come. This is also a good session to come back to if you feel like you could use a quick posterior chain activation or tune-up.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you?  [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Split Stance Side bend w/ Arms Overhead
- Recoil Hamstring Stretch
- Split Stance Hip Hinges
- Single leg Hip Hinge
- Kneeling Hip Extension
- Quadruped w/ Cervical Extension
- Quadruped Chin Tucks
- Double Leg Hip Bridge
- High Plank w/ Alt. Arm Raise
- High Plank w/ Hip Abduction + Tap
- 45° Reverse Fly w/ Reps
- Lat Press on Wall-Reps
- 90° Reverse Fly w/ Reps
- Overhead Reverse Fly w/ Hold
- KickBacks from Toes
- Hamstring Hip Bridge
- Marching Hip Bridge
- Back Extension w/ opposite arm & leg raise
- Downward Dog
- Pigeon Stretch

_Want a strength training routine that covers all the bases? Our Full Body Strength series is exactly what you’re after, offering a well-rounded series of exercises that covers the lower body, core, posterior chain, and upper body. With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time._

​

At this level, we can begin to throw in more upper body and core work compared to previous Full Body sessions. The goal is not to develop big muscles in your arms and chest, but to build basic functional strength to help you improve stability and become a more well-rounded athlete.

​

This extra work is derived from more difficult variations of the foundation moves. While the added upper-body component will decrease the number of reps you can complete in a set, your primary goal remains to nail perfect form. Even though you've been at this for several weeks your nervous system is still learning these movement patterns. Keep focusing on completing the exercise correctly rather than moving quickly.

You’re progressing quite nicely. So nicely, in fact, that you’re ready for a more demanding session. This workout includes compound sets which are more difficult but, most importantly, more beneficial than simply doing more sets of a single move. Since this is a longer session, you may experience considerable fatigue on your first time through. As a result, pay more attention to your form. Your body will want to use as little energy as possible, which can lead to some bad habits when hitting rep after rep of a single move. Thankfully, the constant variation of the compound sets forces you to stay engaged and helps you keep solid form from start to finish.
